name: Ronald van Kempen's conjecture
explained: Kemnitz's conjecture, formulated for the integer lattice Z^2 in two dimensions (n=2), states that for any finite set S of lattice points in the plane (points with integer coordinates), there exists a subset T ⊆ S with exactly 3 points (n+1=3) such that the centroid of T is also a lattice point. This means the average of the x-coordinates and the average of the y-coordinates of the three points must both be integers. Equivalently, the sum of the x-coordinates and the sum of the y-coordinates of the three points must both be divisible by 3.
related_conjectures: Erdős–Ginzburg–Ziv theorem (concerns subset sums modulo n)
Kemnitz's conjecture in higher dimensions (for Z^d with subset size d+1)
